After watching the video, I tried to came up with a solution, which ofc was not successful, but gave me some maybe-good ideas:
1. For every point of a 2D loop, there are infinitely many deltoids inscribed into the loop which contain that point.
2. There is at least one inscribed rhomb for every point of the loop, so that the point is a vertex of the rhomb.
3. If one can show that by continously moving our arbitrary point around the loop, the rhombs undergo a continuous transformation, then there must exist an inscribed square.

Proof of 1:
For each point of the loop, there are at least two points the same distance d (less than the maximum distance) away from that point (can be shown by drawing a small enough circle). Then, draw a straight line from our first point, which is purpendicular to the line connecting the two points mentioned above. It has to pass through another point of the loop! The four points form a deltoid. The same method gives different deltoids for each distance d.

Non-rigorous proof of 2:
Start with an arbitrary point A. Then, consider points of the loop "on the left" of A and "on the right". For every point B "on the left" there is a point C "on the right", so that |AB|=|AC| (see Proof of 1). Let one of the points the furthest from A be "o.t.l." and "o.t.r." at the same time, so that it's the only point except A with this property; let's call it M (from "middle" or "maximum"). OK, here it gets a bit tricky.
Let d_l(B):=|AB|, d_r(C):=|AC|, where the domain of d_l is the set of points "o.t.l." and dom(d_r) is analogous. By moving point B' from A to M, we see that d_l(B') has its local minima (starting with |AA|=0) and maxima (ending with |AM|); same thing with d_r(C').
Now, let's move both B' and C' from A to M, keeping them on respective sides of the loop. Is it possible to do so while preserving d_l(B')=d_r(C')? Yes :) bc each time we hit a local maximum on one side, we can proceed further by going back on the other. Then, when we get to a local minimum on the side where there was a local maximum before, we again switch directions on the other side. We go further and further by kind-of-zigzagin, having d_l(B')=d_r(C'), until we get from A to M "o.t.l." and "o.t.r.".
Why do we need this? It means we can continously change two, and in concequence three of the vertices of an inscribed deltoid with a "constant" vertex A. Now, let's focus on the segment B'C' - it moved from "near A" to "far from A", which means it must have been the same distance from A and from the 4th vertex of the deltoid at least once; somewhere there we got an inscribed rhomb.

Proof of 3:
Imagine an inscribed rhomb ABDC, |AD|≤|BC|. Imagine we transform the rhomb continously, while changing one vertex from A to B, where we get the same rhomb we started with. Since the width and the height of the rhomb changed places, somewhere along the process they were equal. Yes, that means there was an inscribed square :)

Beautiful animations! Mathematically not quite correct though. The "graph" over the interior of the simple closed loop is in fact not a graph in general and therefore cannot be used in the proof in the way explained, at least not easily. It is also not actually needed. If you assume the theorem false then by the the argument in the video there would exist an embedding of the moebius strip into three-space bounding the planar loop, with the interior of the moebius strip being above the plane of the loop. Filling the loop in by the disk that it bounds in the plane would then yield an embedding of the real projective plane into three-space. Since such an embedding does not exist, the theorem must be true.

You describe the 3-d surface that encodes the midpoints and lengths of all lines AC and all lines BD. You then prove that, by folding the final Möbius strip onto this surface, there will always be a point of intersection, and that this point therefore describes a pair of lines that share a midpoint and length and therefore that ABCD forms a rectangle.
Surely each pint on the surface has not only a midpoint and a length but also a slope in the XY plane. When your final point of intersection, you therefor know not only the length and midpoint of the two diagonals but also the slope of each diagonal.
The Möbius strip and the surface, both being surfaces, must join not at a point but at a line PQ in 3D. This line represents the central coordinates of at least one, possibly an infinite number of, rectangles. One of the points on PQ , say R, must represent a meeting of two lines AC and BD whose slopes are orthogonal (if the original conjecture postulating at least one square is true). Therefore, if it can be proved that the line PQ represents the pairs of lines AC,BD that smoothly span intersection angles between 0 and 180 then there will always be a point R whose diagonals are the same length, share a midpoint and crucially cross at 90 degrees , ie ABCD describe a square.

The reason you can't embed a Mobius strip in 3-space with its boundary circle lying in a plane is that if you could, then by reflecting this by the plane you would get an embedding of two Mobius strips glued along their boundaries -- but that's a Klein bottle, which can't be embedded in 3-space (since it's a non-orientable closed surface).

I think I found a proof. So what is a loop? A closed loop on a 2-D Cartesian plane can only contain certain parts especially if loops cross their own path. Straight lines, angels, and curves. So on a 2-D Cartesian plane any vertical line could be said the be the radius of an infinitely large circle. We know what makes a circle a circle is that all points are equally the same distance way from the center. So you pick 4 points equality away from each other to make a square in a circle. Since you can do this with one circle you can do this with any circle no matter the size.
No back to the other parts of the loop. If you have a vertical line you are already 1/4 of the way there to making a square no matter what you do with a the vertical line. If you make an angle with two lines you are 2/4 of the way to making a square no matter what you do. Curves are just a small more visible slice of a circle which we know we can always inscribe a square in.
So here is the proof you really only have three kinds of loops if you can't cross over your own lines. A loop of all straight lines, A loop of all curves, or a loop that is a mix of straight lines and curves.
Since we know when we make any angle with 2 lines it gets us to half of the square no matter what we do It stands to reason any loop that is all lines will always allow you to make a square. A loop that is all curves is just a distorted circle and even if you warp a circle it still maintains its properties of having 4 points equally away from each other even if you can't see or graph those points. A mixed loop is just 2/4 of the square from any angle you can make and the other two can come from any set of curves.
Heck It may be reasonable to say any loop on a 2-D Cartesian plane no matter how you draw it is just a really jumbled up circle and the circle still retains its properties of inscription even if it is warped to the point of not looking like a circle.

The whole mapping between the pairs of points from the 2D rectangle to the Mobius strip does not take into account the distance between the pair of points. A point on the Mobius strip gets mapped to a midpoint of those points on the X-Y plane (Not the X-Y-Z surface!!). Even though the surface in 3D plane in this video is continuous, that doesn’t mean there is a unique distance for every midpoint. Take the parallelogram and the 2 pairs of points on the corners. Their midpoint is the same but different distances.
The Mobuis strip intersecting itself during mapping means that there are two pairs of points that have the same midpoint ONLY!!! Not necessarily the same distance. So this video proves the Inscribed Parallelogram Problem, not the Inscribed Rectangle Problem. Prove me wrong!

Couldn't you scale up the 3D space analogy to find squares?

Take points A, B, C, D

Take the midpoints of lines AB (Side 1) BC (Side 2) CD (Side 3) AD (Side 4) AC, BD, Side 1 | Side 3, & Side 2 | Side 4.

So you have the midpoints of all four sides, the cross like you'd use to find rectangles, and the cross between the midpoints of the sides.

When all of your central midpoints (AC, BD, S1|S3, S2|S4) line up, you have a square.

Obviously computing this takes way more effort, but still - it's worth a shot.

There is a serious error here. It is shown that the mapping of points from the Möbius Strip to the plane is not injective (at least two points on the Möbius Strip map to the same point on the plane). Hence, two unordered pairs of points have the same midpoint; this is not the same as showing that the distances are equal. Two points can “overlap” but represent different distances (take for instance points along the axes of an ellipse, the mid point of the major axis and the mid point of the minor axis are the same).

The confusion lies in the final animation; the Möbius Strip is shown to be mapped onto the surface when it really should be mapped to the plane under the surface. The Möbius Strip represents the domain (not the codomain.

Obviously what is trying to be proved is true; however, something needs to be added to this to make it a valid argument.

It should be noted that the boundary of a Möbius strip CAN be mapped to the plane in such a way that it does NOT intersect itself. An example of such an embedding is called the Sudanese Surface. The fact this embedding exists defies intuition.

I highly recommend looking up this surface since it shows one how quickly assumptions based on physical intuition can fail in topology.

This surface does not break this proof since the function as described in the video is nonnegative and thus the embedding of the Möbius strip must be on one side of the plane. This condition fails for the Sudanese surface.

You seemed surprised that the mapping lead to the Mobius Strip. You shouldn't have been, when you consider that there was a minor mistake in your analogy of mapping leading to the torus. You first rolled the coordinate plane into a cylinder and then connected the ends into a torus, but you forgot that the ends of the cylinder should be rotated ninety degrees before they are joined. One would be rotated left and the other would be rotated right and they would end up one hundred eighty degrees opposed as they should be. This accounts for the twist in the Mobius shape (not strip) and the distillation of the torus from the ordered pairs to just the unordered pairs.

It seems to me that the proof you have shown goes half way to proving the square within a closed loop. The proof thus far is based on a mobius strip crossing itself in order to lay its outer edge on the closed curve. But two parts of a surface do not just cross at a point, rather their crossing describes a line, along which rectangles will center. Now I'm not a topologist so I can't do a formal proof, but I think this line I mention would have the A and B points touching at one end (along with the C and D points touching, which is still a rectangle with only one dimension), and the B and C points touching, along with the A and D points touching at the other end. Now the definition of a square is the same as that of the rectangle, except AC and BD are perpendicular. With the center marked as O, we would say that the first end of this intersection line would have AOB at zero degrees, while the other end would have AOB at 180 degrees. Since this is continuous line then there must be at least one point on the line where AOB is 90 degrees, a square.

If there is a continuous band of solutions to the inscribed rectangle problem, there must always be a solution to the inscribed square problem. Start with any arbitrary solution, then shift the lines around the loop of Inscribed rectangle solutions until the original lines swap positions. In the construction of the quadrilateral, there must 2 supplementary angles created by pair of lines by the result of the midpoint mapping. If these lines are swapped around this continuous band until one line lands on the other line’s initial poisiton, the change in the angles must also be continuous therefore, no matter what the value of the two angles are at the arbitrary initial point, the angles are swapped when the pair of lines are moved around the continuous band. Therefore there must be a point where the supplementary angles are equivalent. If the Supplementary Angles are equivalent both angles must be 90 degrees. Therefore these lines are perpendicular. These are the known properties of this point: it lies on the continuous band of solutions to the inscribed rectangle problem & the angles of the diagonals are perpendicular to each other. The only possible shape described by these properties is a square. Therefore, if there is a continuous band of solutions to the inscribed rectangle problem, there must be at least one solution to the inscribed square problem. This should shrink the problem down to proving that there is a continuous band of solutions to the inscribed rectangle problem.

If you colour every point on that surface (the one whose height is the distance between the points), by the angle of the line the points make, considering only angles 0 to pi (to avoid confusing reversing issues), the colour on the edge must vary continuously, given that the curve is smooth, so the angle varies continuously.

As well, the whole surface must be coloured smoothly except on the curve itself and then at distinct points. You can imagine taking a line, held at a particular angle, being moved through the curve. Where it intersects the curve, the line segments drawn between pairs of points correspond to individual points on the surface. Holding the line at that particular angle determines that those points on the surface have the same colour, even as you vary the position of the line through the curve. When the line just begins to meet the curve, a streak of that colour will move up the surface. These streaks will be continuous, and must always go back to the curve at another point. For a given angle, one can picture some streaks over the odd surface, all some particular colour.
Varying the angle slightly will vary the colour and position of those streaks continuously, except occasionally at the curve. Where streaks intersect correspond to either 'zeroes' where many very different colours intersect, or lines on the surface where it intersects itself, which correspond to rectangles on the original curve.
To create a square, one needs a rectangle whose diagonals meet at pi/2 radians. This corresponds to points on curves of self-intersection on the 'coloured distance surface' whose colours are pi/2 radians apart.

Depending on the nature of such intersection lines, different things must happen. An intersection of one point indicates a strange and lucky coincidence, and probably cannot be guaranteed to correspond to a square under simply definable circumstances.
An intersection of an open curve may include a point corresponding to a square if the difference between angles on the curve goes through pi/2, which can be determined concretely through certain combinations of values at the endpoints of the open curve. It may be possible to determine how these characteristics generally with the direction the colours change in.

An intersection of a closed curve, or possibly a curve which also intersects the original curve, indicates that we need to consider the direction the colours change in, along that intersection curve. If, for the different parts of the surface, the colours change in opposite directions, and if the colours go through the full range of colours and the 'winding number,' similar to as in your 2D equation solving video, is non-zero for both those different parts of the surface on the intersection curve, then one of those points on that curve will correspond to a square, guaranteed. If this characteristic cannot be proven generally, then weaker solutions must be carefully crafted, and will probably be much more difficult to prove.

A good start to working with certain parts of this framework would be mapping these colours on the surface to the complex plain, and perhaps considering a function of z whose output angle corresponds to twice the output angle on the surface.
Remapping the colours back to the möbius strip may, or may not, provide helpful insight, but this is terrifyingly difficult to visualize. A note about that coloured möbius strip is that the edge will not, in most cases, be coloured simply, but must have a 'winding number' the same as for the case of the circle.

There is a missing argument around the 5 minute mark. How do you deal with the case that one pair of points shares a midpoint with another pair of points, but they have different distances? This means that if you were drilling into the surface from the top, the drill would hit the surface twice on the way down. An easy case to think about is a loop that is like an elongated hot dog shape. A line between two points on the ends would share a midpoint with a line between two points on the middle sides (i.e. a if you cut a hot dog long-ways, that cut would share a midpoint with a cut done sideways across the middle). But the length of those two cuts (i.e. distance) are vastly different.

When I first saw this lovely video I was deeply impressed... so fascinating, elegant, and powerful (as you can see from my earlier comment, below). But upon further reflection, I find I'm still confused a bit. The central problem comes at the end, involving the mapping from a Möbius strip to the plane of the loop. It is clear that the space of the Möbius strip must fold atop itself in order that the single (red) boundary map to the loop in the plane. Thus there will be regions on the plane that have two points from the Möbius strip and thus two different line segments joining different points (a,b) and (c,d). But I don't see why this mapping guarantees these two line segments must share the same mid-point, and (more importantly) the line segments be the ones yielding the solution (i.e., have the same length transepting the loop). After all, the Möbius strip must be deformed and warped to fit within the loop and I see no guarantee this required deformation forces lines sharing the same mid-point to overlap. There must be some implied fixed-point theorem invoked in this step, but I don't see it explained in the video. Even if there were some fixed-point theorem invoked, such a theorem typically ensures that there is one fixed point. But for the inscribed rectangle problem, the overlapping must be for the particular solution point. I don't see how that is ensured either.

I may go look at the original Vaughan (1977) paper to answer these, but I wish I were just a bit more convinced by this lovely video, which is clearly the result of extensive and diligent work.

-When two planes of a mobius strip intersect, the intersection is a line, not a point (although an infinitely small line in some cases, as would be for a true circle).
-All intersection lines eventually loop back on themselves.
-On the UNAVOIDABLE intersection line (there should only be one) tracing it around once should rotate the rectangle 90 degrees.
-If a continues set of rectangles exist such that a landscape version transforms into a portrait version, there must be some square that exists in the intermediate space.

Now, I'm not sure how magnitude would translate onto the mobeus strip, but if you made a second plane, which represented the magnitude of the lines created by the unordered pairs, but drawn into the zed axis at the points themselves, instead of at the midpoint, then followed the same process as the midpoint plane, you could possibly find some geometric relation between those 8 points and their distance to the overlap on the folded mobeus connected to the closed loop. Another idea would be to draw a cross sectional plane at the point of overlap on the folded mobeus and find 4 points whose arc length to the overlap would be equivalent, which might yield the result of finding 4 ordered pairs with equal magnitude and whose midpoints share a common distance to the midpoint of the rectangle, in essence proving that there is a square which can be drawn on that closed loop.

Another strategy would be to take the midpoints themselves and apply the same strategy as with the unordered pairs. Find the distance between them, their midpoint and project another line from that midpoint to create a second mobeus geometry related to unordered pairs of midpoints from the original set of unordered pairs of points on the closed loop. Now you'd need to find a relation between 4 of these new midpoint and the overlapped midpoint represented on the original mobeus strip. Now what sort of shape this would form and whether there would be some recognizable pattern between these 4 points and the center is beyond my limited knowledge of topology. I think, though, if you could find 2 or 4 of these midpoint relationships which fall directly under the midpoint fold of the original mobeus strip, you may very well find a square there. Then if you could expand this pattern and find that it exists for all possible closed loop geometries, you may very well prove the existence of a square on every closed loop.

I'm still a few years away from topology, so I'm not sure how the magnitudes and distances of these points would relate to the mobeus after it is connected back to the edge of the closed loop, so it might all be nonsense.

What I would like to see, if you read this, is a short clip of the same process you did in this video for the rectangle applied to a closed loop with a known square. I'd like to see the midpoints of the 4 edges of the square projected onto the geometry formed by the connected mobeus. Maybe apply that methodology to 2 or 3 different shapes to see if there is any discernable pattern existing on the original mobeus geometry, all related to the common midpoint represented by the fold. A persistent pattern might provide the grounds for further investigation

So for the square problem, you'd need the rectangle, with the added requirement that the angle at which those lines intersect be 90 degrees. I'm wondering if you could define a topological shape which would represent not only the midpoint and magnitude, but the angle at which those points intersect. Or perhaps the ability to define an object which would tell you the number of lines made with the same magnitude, and find some geometric relationship between the magnitude of 4 lines and the overlap on the rectangular application on the folded mobeus...

Amazing video. Loved the beauty and simplicity of the proof.

As for "who cares about topology": I am a PhD student in theoretical physics and we very much care! I work in a field called condensed matter physics (which is usually considered to be a more practical field), more specifically on phases of matter called "topological order". The materials we study have current & future potential applications in many fields, both in electronics and in building (topologically robust) quantum computers.

Papers in this field make use of many advanced advanced tools from algebraic topology & category theory. For example: various types of homology/cohomology theories (de Rham, singular, group cohomology etc), generalized cohomology (K-theoretical classification of fiber bundles & characteristic classes), homotopy theory, cobordism theory, TQFT's (modular functors) etc. For example the computations done on a quantum computer based on topological order, will be very closely related to knot invariants (like Jones polynomials), representations of braid groups and monoidal categories.

Even many Nobel prizes in physics make use of some tools from topology, including the latest one given. So all in all, topology (and many other advanced field of mathematics) are surprisingly useful beyond abstract mathematics.

What about curves that have singular points (curves that intersect themselves but are closed, i.e. are not Jordan)? Intuitively we can just "remove" the singularity and imagine the curve in question is Jordan, but how does the proof change?

Hold on, if you took an ellipse, and performed the function with the two most distant points on the long axis, you'd get a point at the exact center of the ellipse with the height of the long axis. If you did the same with the two most distant points on the short axis, you'd get a point at the exact center of the ellipse with the height of the short axis. These would be THE SAME OUTPUT POINT AT TWO DIFFERENT HEIGHTS. In fact, if you took any two points on opposite ends of the ellipse, the midpoint would be the center of the ellipse, while the distance would vary infinitely. Thus the function is not one-to-one, and does not produce a surface, but a SOLID.

So let me sum this up. The möbius stip represents points that are a mid-point to any two points of your choice on the squiggly line, and the edge of the strip represents that line. The fact that you folded the plane and transformed it into a möbius strip and not a torus means that you've eliminated all excessive variations of any two points (meaning (a,b) and (b,a) is now the same thing, and therefore can't be used as two distinct lines). When you then map the strip onto the weird mountain shape and you still get intersections, it means that there are two distinct lines that have the same mid-point, and that they have the same length (if they had different lengths, then not only it wouldn't be a rectangle, but their mid-points mapped onto the 3D thing wouldn't share the same z coordinate, so there wouldn't be any intersection). Therefore, all intersections show a presence of a rectangle, and since mapping the edge of a möbius strip onto a flat surface MUST lead to an intersection, it means that all squiggly lines contain a rectangle. Is that correct?

Also, to find a square, I guess you would have to verify whether lines (a,d) and (b,c) are the same as (a,b) and (c,d), meaning there would have to be a quadruple intersection in the 3D graph, since a square has a 4-fold symmetry. But I'm not sure.

How is the Inscribed square problem unsolved? Take 2 line segments of equal length in space that are separate and are not parallel. Placing the 2 nearest enpoints close together, draw a perfect arc connecting them.....the other 2 end points, draw another perfect arc.....there is no way to get a square out of any 4 points on this surface. Therefore, if any squiggle results in an image close to this in similar fashion, then you will also not be able to form a square.

I'm sure you've probably left out some sort of rule in drawing the squiggle, possibly it "must be concave" or something....but as it stands based on just what you've stated and nothing more, I have provided proof that it cannot be done as laid out.

If you have an ellipse with width 4 and height 2, then how high will this surface be at the point (0, 0)?
You might say "2" because you can take the points (0, 1) and (0, -1) on the ellipse which have a distance 2 and midpoint (0, 0).
But you can also say "4" because you can take the points (2, 0) and (-2, 0) on the ellipse which have a distance 4 and midpoint (0, 0).
Even worse, you might say "√10" because you can take the points (√2, ½√2) and (-√2, -½√2) on the ellipse which have a distance √10 and midpoint (0, 0).
Actually, for any real number in the closed interval [2, 4] there exist two points on the ellipse which have that distance and midpoint (0, 0).
